'''Edward Wegman''' is an American [[statistician]] and a professor of statistics at [[George Mason University]]. He holds a [[Ph.D.]] in [[mathematical statistics]] and is a Fellow of the [[American Statistical Association]], a Senior Member of the [[IEEE]], and past chair of the [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]] Committee on Applied and Theoretical Statistics. In addition to his work in the field of statistical computing, Wegman [[Wegman report|contributed a report]] to a Congressional hearing on [[climate change]] at the request of [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Rep. [[Joe Barton]]. Wegman's report supported criticisms of the methodology of two specific paleoclimate studies into the [[temperature record of the past 1000 years]], and argued that climate scientists were excessively isolated from the statistical mainstream. Subsequently, significant portions of Wegman's report were found to have been copied without attribution from a variety of sources, including Wikipedia, and a publication based on the report was retracted.<ref name="throw-away"/><ref name="retracted"/><ref name="wp-copying"/>

== Career ==
Wegman, a [[St. Louis, Missouri]] native, received a B.S. in mathematics from [[Saint Louis University]] in 1965. He then went to graduate school at the [[University of Iowa]], where he earned an M.S. in 1967 and a Ph.D. in 1968, both in mathematical statistics. He held a faculty position at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|University of North Carolina]] for ten years.  In 1978, Wegman joined the [[Office of Naval Research]], in which he headed the Mathematical Sciences Division.<ref name=ioalum>{{cite web | url = http://www.iowalum.com/daa/wegman.html | publisher = University of Iowa | title = Alumni Association distinguished alumni awards | deadurl=yes}}</ref> Later, Wegman served as the first program director of the Ultra High Speed Computing basic research program for the [[Strategic Defense Initiative]]'s Innovative Science and Technology Office.  He joined the faculty of George Mason University in 1986 and developed a master’s degree program in statistical science.<ref name=ioalum/>

Wegman is credited with coining the phrase "computational statistics" and developing a high-profile research program around the concept that computing resources could transform statistical techniques.  He also has been the associate editor of seven academic journals, a member of numerous editorial boards, and the author of more than 160 papers and five books.  Wegman is a member of the [[American Statistical Association]], a former president of the [[International Association for Statistical Computing]], and a past chairman of the Committee on Applied and Theoretical Statistics for the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]].<ref name=ioalum/> Wegman received the 2002 Founders Award from the American Statistical Association for "over thirty years of exceptional service and leadership to the American Statistical Association."<ref name="throw-away">{{cite journal | journal = [[American Scientist]] | first1 = Andrew | last1 = Gelman | authorlink1 = Andrew Gelman | first2 = Thomas | last2 = Babsøll | title = To Throw Away Data: Plagiarism as a Statistical Crime | url = http://www.americanscientist.org/issues/pub/to-throw-away-data-plagiarism-as-a-statistical-crime/1 | volume = 101 | issue= 3 | pages = 168}}</ref><ref>[http://www.amstat.org/careers/foundersaward.cfm ASA Founders Award winners]</ref>

== Energy and Commerce hearing & plagiarism allegations ==
{{main|Wegman report}}

In 2006, Republican Congressman [[Joe Barton]] chose Wegman to assist the House [[Energy and Commerce Committee]] in its inquiry criticizing the multi-proxy paleoclimate reconstructions which had been dubbed the "[[Hockey stick graph]]". Wegman [[Wegman report|produced a report]] and offered testimony supporting published papers disputing the methodology and data used by the climate scientists.<ref>{{Citation

| first2  = Yasmin H.

| format      =pdf
| archiveurl  =http://web.archive.org/web/20060716210311/http://energycommerce.house.gov/108/home/07142006_Wegman_Report.pdf
| archivedate = 16 July 2006
}}</ref> The legitimacy of this investigation was disputed, and [[Sherwood Boehlert]] as chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Science, Space and Technology]] arranged for an investigation by the [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]], the [[North Report]] which found that the Wegman committee's conclusions lacked substance.<ref name="Powell2013">{{cite book|author=James Lawrence Powell|title=The Inquisition of Climate Science|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5TBFAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT230|date=13 August 2013|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-52784-2|pages=229–230}}</ref>

In October 2010, [[George Mason University]] (GMU) announced they were conducting a formal investigation into charges of [[plagiarism]] and  misconduct related to the Wegman Report.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/sciencefair/post/2010/10/wegman-plagiarism-investigation-/1 | title = University investigating prominent climate science critic | work = USA Today | date = October 8, 2010}}</ref> In November 2010, ''[[USA Today]]'' reported that the "review of the 91-page report, by three experts... found repeated instances of passages lifted word for word and what appear to be thinly disguised paraphrases" of wording taken from the textbook ''Paleoclimatology: Reconstructing Climates of the Quaternary'', as well as erroneous citations of data.<ref name="usat2010-11-21"/> Wegman criticized the "speculation and conspiracy theory" in the original allegations, and said that "these attacks are unprecedented" in his long career.<ref name="usat2010-11-21">{{cite news |title=Experts claim 2006 climate report plagiarized |work=USA Today |first = Dan | last = Vergano | url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/climate/globalwarming/2010-11-21-climate-report-questioned_N.htm |date=November 22, 2010 }}</ref> A ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' editorial in May 2011 called the delays in GMU's inquiry "disheartening," as "long misconduct investigations do not serve anyone, except perhaps university public-relations departments that might hope everyone will have forgotten about a case by the time it wraps up," and urged resolution "as speedily as possible while allowing time for due process."<ref name=Nature>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/473419b | title = Copy and paste | journal = Nature | volume = 473 | issue = 7348 | pages = 419–420 | year = 2011 | pmid =  21614031| pmc = }}</ref>

In May 2011 the journal ''Computational Statistics and Data Analysis'' retracted a 2008 [[social network analysis]] based on the Wegman Report by Yasmin Said, Wegman, and others, because the paper used portions of other authors' writings without sufficient attribution.<ref name="retracted">{{Cite journal | last1 = Said | first1 = Y. | last2 = Wegman | first2 = E. | last3 = Sharabati | first3 = W. | last4 = Rigsby | first4 = J. | title = Social networks of author–coauthor relationships | doi = 10.1016/j.csda.2007.07.021 | journal = Computational Statistics & Data Analysis | volume = 52 | issue = 4 | pages = 2177–2184 | year = 2008 | pmid =  | pmc = }}{{retracted|intentional= yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2011/06/journal-retracts-disputed-network.html | title = Journal Retracts Disputed Network Analysis Paper on Climate | work = Science | date= June 2, 2011}}</ref> The lawyer for both authors said they stood by their work.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.usatoday.com/weather/climate/globalwarming/2011-05-15-climate-study-plagiarism-Wegman_n.htm | title = Climate study gets pulled after charges of plagiarism | first = Dan | last = Vergano | work = USA Today | date = May 15, 2011}}</ref> Subsequently, ''USA Today'' reported additional concerns about separate 2009 review article authored by Wegman and Said which contained material copied without attribution from Wikipedia. Wegman, his attorney, and George Mason University declined to comment on the allegations.<ref name="wp-copying">{{cite news | work= [[USA Today]] | first = Dan | last = Vergano | title = More Wikipedia copying from climate critics | url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/sciencefair/post/2011/10/more-wikipedia-copying-from-climate-critics/1 | date = October 5, 2011 | accessdate = October 12, 2011}}</ref>

Ultimately, an investigation by George Mason University was completed in February 2012. The investigation found that regarding the Congressional Wegman Report, "no misconduct was involved"; while "extensive paraphrasing of another work did occur, in a background section... the work was repeatedly referenced and the committee found that the paraphrasing did not constitute misconduct". A separate university committee examining Said & Wegman's 2008 publication, based on the Wegman report, found "that plagiarism occurred in contextual sections of the article, as a result of poor judgment for which Professor Wegman, as team leader, must bear responsibility." The university's reports were not made public, but it was announced that Wegman was to receive an "official letter of reprimand" as a consequence.<ref name="usatoday.23212">{{cite news | work= [[USA Today]] | first = Dan | last = Vergano  | title = University reprimands climate science critic for plagiarism | url = http://content.usatoday.com/communities/sciencefair/post/2012/02/george-mason-university-reprimands-edward-wegmand-/1?csp=34news#.T0agQ3LDn_F | date = February 22, 2012 | accessdate = 23 February 2012 }}</ref> The decision was decried by [[Raymond S. Bradley]], one of the scientists whose work had been copied without attribution by Said & Wegman; Bradley argued that the findings would encourage GMU students to think it acceptable to copy work without attribution.<ref name="usatoday.23212"/> Writing in ''[[American Scientist]]'' in 2013, [[Andrew Gelman]] described Wegman as "perhaps the most prominent statistician to have repeatedly published material written by others without attribution."<ref name="throw-away"/>
